;COVID-19 大流行已改变了美国人的工作方式。

;
;
;

;在大流行之前，只有 5.7% 的人在家工作。但商业顾问麦肯锡公司最近的一份报告发现，2022 年，58% 的人每周至少有一天在家工作。

;
;
;

;Ryan Luby 帮助撰写了这份报告。他说，办公室需要改变，因为工作场所的;角色;已经改变。

;
;
;

;Aditya Sanghvi 供职于麦肯锡公司的房地产业务。他说：“办公室突然成为一种选择。这是一个;选项;。对于某人来说，办公室必须比在家工作和;忍受;通勤才能进入办公室更好。”

;
;
;

;需要改变办公空间更加;关注;工作场所的社区。 “当你到达办公室时，如果你没有与其他人;交流;，那么你可能就不在那儿了，”卢比说。

;
;
;

;他补充道，“办公室应该是进行团队合作的地方。”

;
;
;

;Sanghvi 补充道，在新的工作空间中，人们应该感觉“没有某人是否与您一起坐在办公室或某人在视频中的区别。”

;
;
;
;
;

;

;未来的办公室甚至可以帮助员工履行个人职责。

;
;
;

;“很多人工作的原因之一桑格维说：“从家里回来后，他们必须去接孩子或照顾狗。” “那么，如果大楼里有[动物]护理怎么办？如果大楼里有儿童保育设施怎么办？”

;
;
;

;Sanghvi 认为拥有办公空间的公司应该更积极地改变工作空间，以适应新的生活方式。

;
;
;

;查克·哈迪 (Chuck Hardy) 是 GSA 的首席;建筑师;。他负责管理 GSA 的工作场所创新实验室，该实验室位于华盛顿特区该组织总部内，占地 25,000 平方英尺

;;文件 - 沙特国家水务公司的亚洲工人在道路建筑工地工作在首都利雅得。沙特阿拉伯。 （Fayez Nureldine/法新社）;
;

;沙特阿拉伯是一个干燥的地方。在许多地区，人们依靠将波斯湾和红海的咸水转化为可饮用的淡水。这个过程称为;海水淡化;。

;

;海水淡化中心为王国的城镇提供饮用水。然而，观察人士表示，海水淡化过程对环境不利，因为它主要使用石油和天然气。

;

;王储穆罕默德·本·萨勒曼的目标之一是使沙特阿拉伯成为商业和商业领域的领导者;旅游业。为此，该国必须满足不断增长的水需求。

;

;但沙特阿拉伯的环境目标是到 2060 年实现;净零排放;。因此，该国领导人表示他们希望减少碳气体的产生量。有人说碳气体正在使地球大气变暖。

;

;该国东部的一家海水淡化厂使用;太阳能电池板;。 Jazlah 工厂是沙特阿拉伯第一座大规模利用太阳能进行海水淡化的工厂。官员们表示，这些电池板每年将有助于减少 6 万吨碳排放。

;

;需要更多像 Jazlah 这样的项目，因为穆罕默德王子还有另一个目标。他希望到 2040 年将人口增加到 1 亿。该国目前人口约为 3220 万。

;

;Marco Arcelli 是 ACWA Power 的首席执行官，该公司运营 Jazlah 发电厂。他说，通常“人口增长，人口的生活质量就会提高”。这意味着未来将需要更多的水。

;

;历史学家迈克尔·克里斯托弗·洛 (Michael Christopher Low) 表示，使用海水淡化是一个“要么成败”的问题。他在美国犹他大学研究了王国与水资源的斗争。刘特佐表示，这个问题事关沙特阿拉伯的生存问题。与此同时，他补充说，如何进行海水淡化“存在限制”，以免影响环境。

;

;;目前化石燃料的使用;

;

;盐水转换公司（或 SWCC）是一家在沙特阿拉伯经营海水淡化和发电厂的政府公司。该公司表示，其 30 个中心每天生产 1150 万立方米。但增长是有代价的，特别是在使用石油或天然气的中心。

;

;法新社报道称，到 2010 年，沙特海水淡化厂使用了 150 万桶;桶;海水。每天油。这占当今产量的 15% 以上。

;

;SWCC 表示，希望到 2025 年减少 3700 万吨碳排放。该公司希望通过放弃使用热量来分离的工厂来实现这一目标。 SWCC 在其最新报告中表示，太阳能发电量预计将从目前的 120 兆瓦增至 770 兆瓦。但这需要多长时间尚不清楚。

;

;未来，毫无疑问沙特阿拉伯将能够建造生产所需水所需的系统。

;

;“他们我们已经在一些最具挑战性的环境中做到了这一点，例如红海大规模海水淡化以及向麦加和麦地那圣城的高地提供淡化水，”劳伦特·兰伯特说。他在多哈研究生院工作。

;

;在王国各地的海水淡化厂，沙特员工都了解他们的工作有多么重要。

;

;Ras Al-Khair 中心生产 110 万立方米海水每天 740,000 米水来自热技术，其余来自其他工艺。由于需求量大，该工厂难以生产足够的淡水。

;

;大部分水都流向利雅得。该市每天需要160万立方米。一位未获准与媒体交谈且身份不明的员工表示，到 2030 年，每天的需求量可能高达 600 万立方米。

;

;;沙特海水淡化简史;

;

;沙特阿拉伯在 100 多年前首次转向海水淡化。在奥斯曼帝国统治期间，政府官员为参加朝觐的穆斯林旅行者使用;过滤;机器，他们不得不应对缺水和霍乱的问题。

;

;饮用水一直是一个问题沙特阿拉伯自 1932 年建国以来一直致力于此。这引发了地质研究，也有助于确定该国巨大的石油和天然气供应量。自 1970 年起，领导人就监督了王国现代海水淡化系统的诞生。

;

;;
;;;
;
;

;考虑一次请某人喝茶、咖啡或苏打水。您使用了哪些类型的术语和结构？

;
;
;

;在本周的日常语法中，我们将探讨语法与社交情境之间的联系点。我们将讨论如何询问别人是否想喝一杯。您将了解;情态动词;以及;正式;和;非正式;类型的问题。

;
;
;

;让我们从一些重要的术语和想法开始。

;
;
;

;;情态动词 ;

;
;
;

;情态动词起着核心作用在关于咖啡或茶等饮料的日常讨论中。

;
;
;

;情态动词是改变主要动词含义的简短单词。它们表达了说话者的;态度;——某件事是否被允许、必要、可能等等。

;
;
;

;在英语中，我们有很多情态动词。但出于今天课程的目的，让我们仔细注意其中两个：would 和 can。

;
;
;

;我们通常使用“would”来礼貌地提出问题或做出礼貌的表示。提供。我们使用“can”来达到同样的目的，尽管它有点不太正式。

;
;
;

;让我们举个例子。想象一下您在家里或在餐厅工作。您想为您的客人或顾客提供一杯饮料。我们有两种方法可以做到这一点 - 一种涉及“would”，另一种涉及“can”。

;
;
;

;所以，你可能会问：

;
;
;

;;你想喝点什么吗？;

;
;
;

;或者

; ;
;

;;我可以给你喝点东西吗？;

;
;
;

;之间的主要区别我们的两个问题是礼貌程度。一般来说，“would”被认为更加礼貌和正式。

;
;
;

;“would”和“can”在许多情况下都是可以接受的。您的房客或顾客肯定会很高兴听到其中任何一个。

;
;
;

;;与朋友、同学、家人;

;
;
;

;现在让我们考虑一种不同的情况。也许您和朋友出去了，想请他们喝点东西。我们可以用“would”和“can”礼貌地提出建议，例如：

;
;
;

;;Would you like to get tea? 你想喝茶吗？ ;

;
;
;

;或者

;
;
;

;;我能给你一个咖啡？;

;
;
;

;但是我们也可以使用助动词“do”来询问是或否问题。例如，您可能会问朋友：

;
;
;

;;你想喝杯咖啡吗？;

;
;
;

;或者

;
;
;

;;你想;抢;吗喝一杯？;

;
;
;

;这样的结构很友好，但不太正式。因此，您可能不想与老师或老板一起使用它们，除非您与他们非常亲密。

;
;
;

;;练习;;

;
;

;现在让我们花一些时间来讨论这些想法。

;
;
;

;想象一下您正在与另一家公司的代表主持一场商务会议。您的访客进入会议室，您决定为他们提供一些饮料。您会如何提出报价？

;
;
;

;暂停音频以考虑您的答案。

;
;
;

;有几种可能的答案，但是最好的两个选择涉及“愿意”或“可以”，例如：

;
;
;

;;你想喝点什么吗？;

;
;
;

;或者

;
;
;

;;我可以给你喝点东西吗?;

;
;
;

;这两句话在官方场合是礼貌且可以接受的。

;
;
;

;现在考虑以下句子：

;
;
;

;;你想喝点什么吗？;

;
;
;

;为什么这句话不是正式商务会议的最佳选择？

;
;
;

;这个问题不是很正式，也不是特别礼貌。所以，“你想喝点什么吗？”可能不是与其他公司的代表一起使用的最佳选择。

;
;
;

;但是，对于家人和好朋友呢？他们通常很乐意听到这个问题！

;
;
;

;;结束语;

;
;
;

;今天我们探讨了一些与日常情况相关的关键想法 - 邀请某人喝一杯，为客人提供一些饮料。

;
;
;

;当然，还有其他方式询问其他人是否想喝点东西。然而，我们今天探讨的结构是最常用的结构，因为它们在大多数情况下都运行良好。

;

; Fri, 22 Sep 2023 06:07:02 +0800 Study: Earth Outside ‘Safe Operating Space for Humanity’https://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/study-earth-outside-safe-operating-space-for-humanity-/7274708.html
;;2023 年 9 月 20 日星期三 21:55:02 GMT;
;;
;;文件 - 2023 年 8 月 11 日，雾霾笼罩了印度尼西亚雅加达的主要商业区。 （美联社照片/Dita Alangkara，档案）;
;

;国际研究人员的一项新研究表明，地球的九项健康指标中有六项超出了“人类安全运行空间”。该研究补充说，其余三项措施中有两项正朝着错误的方向发展。

;

;国际科学家在《科学进展》上发表了这项研究。他们说，地球的气候、生物多样性、土地、淡水、营养物污染和人造化合物都超出了“人类安全操作空间”。

;

;科学家们表示，只有酸度海洋的健康、空气的健康和臭氧层都在被认为安全的范围内。

;

;臭氧层主要位于大气层的高层，可防止危险的太阳辐射到达地球表面.

;

;但该研究警告说，海洋和空气污染都在朝着错误的方向发展。

;

;约翰·罗克斯特罗姆 (Johan Rockstrom) 是一位气候科学家，他帮助撰写了这项研究。他是德国波茨坦气候影响研究所所长。他说：“我们的情况非常糟糕。”他将地球比作一个虚弱的病人。

;

;2009 年，Rockstrom 和其他研究人员创建了九个“边界区域”，并利用对它们的测量来判断地球的健康状况。最新研究继续了 2015 年类似研究的研究。最新研究在不安全列表中添加了第六个区域。

;

;Rockstrom 表示，地球上的水已从安全变为“不安全”。 ”科学家们表示，这是由于河流径流造成的。他们表示，更好的测量和对问题的理解表明存在问题。

;
;;;文件 - 随着中西部三位数的高温指数持续上升，一名妇女在夕阳下的剪影，2023 年 8 月 20 日，密苏里州堪萨斯城。一项新研究称，地球正在超出其“人类安全运行空间”。 （美联社照片/Charlie Riedel，档案）;
;

;Rockstrom 表示，这些边界将决定地球的未来。他补充说，这九项措施已被其他研究“科学地确立”。如果地球能够;管理;这九项措施，地球或多或少是安全的。但事实并非如此，他说。

;

;这九项措施以不同的方式进行了比较。该团队使用计算机;模拟;来预测未来。例如，他们会根据地球平均温度的升高做出预测。研究小组发现，如果一个区域受到温度变化的严重影响，那么所有区域都会受到严重影响。研究小组还发现，如果一个领域得到改善，所有领域都会得到改善。

;

;科学家们表示，模拟表明，帮助气候变化的最有力方法之一是清理土地和拯救森林。研究称，将森林恢复到 20 世纪末的水平将提供自然区域来储存二氧化碳，而不是在空气中储存二氧化碳，因为二氧化碳会在空气中滞留热量。

;

;Rockstrom 补充说，生物多样性处于最令人不安的领域，但确实如此没有得到那么多的关注。

;

;但是，研究表明臭氧层正在改善。这表明，当世界及其领导人决定解决问题时，问题就可以得到解决。

;

;尼尔·多纳休 (Neil Donahue) 是卡内基梅隆大学化学和环境教授。他说，“在大多数情况下，我们知道如何做一些事情”来改善剩余的问题。

;

;一些生物多样性科学家，如杜克大学的斯图尔特·皮姆 (Stuart Pimm)，对 Rockstrom 的方法提出了质疑，称这些方法并不可行。价值不菲。

;

;格兰杰·摩根是卡内基梅隆大学环境工程教授，并未参与这项研究。他说，“专家们对于极限到底在哪里，或者地球上不同系统可能;相互作用;的程度没有达成一致，但我们已经非常接近了。”

;

;摩根说他经常说，如果我们不减少对地球的伤害，“我们就完蛋了。”他补充道，“这篇论文说我们更有可能被烤焦了。”

;

;我是 Gregory Stachel。

;;美国图书馆协会于 2023 年 9 月 20 日星期三报道称，学校和公共图书馆的数量可能会在 2023 年达到历史新高，超过 2022 年的创纪录速度。（美联社照片/Rick Bowmer，档案）;
;

;美国图书馆协会 (ALA) 表示美国的禁书和禁书尝试继续增加。该组织指出，目前的努力已从学校扩展到公共图书馆。

;

;ALA 表示，2023 年前 8 个月，图书馆资料和服务面临 695 项;挑战;，涉及 1,915 名长期以来，人们一直试图从学校图书馆中删除他们认为具有冒犯性的书籍。但 ALA 周三表示，今年，学校和向公众开放的图书馆面临的挑战几乎均等。

;

;黛博拉·考德威尔-斯通 (Deborah Caldwell-Stone) 是该协会知识自由办公室的负责人。她说：“;讽刺;是，有一些;审查员;说，那些不想从学校撤回书籍的人可以去公共图书馆。”; p>;

;ALA 将挑战定义为“向图书馆或学校提出的正式书面;投诉;，要求因内容或适当性而删除材料。”

;

;许多其中的挑战来自“自由妈妈”组织。该组织在全国范围内组织了行动，并呼吁家长对向儿童提供的书籍进行更多控制。

;

;“过去大约是一对一的;比例;，其中家长would complain about an individual book, like in the days when many were objecting to Harry Potter,” Caldwell-Stone said. “Now you have people turning up at meetings and asking that 100 ;titles; be removed.”

;

;Earlier this year, the Chicago-based association issued its yearly top 10 list of books most objected to in 2022. Many of them included racial and/or LGBTQ issues. Maia Kobabe's ;Gender Queer; topped the list, followed by George Johnson's ;All Boys Aren't Blue; and Nobel literature-prize winner Toni Morrison's ;The Bluest Eye;.

;

;Teachers and librarians have been criticized a lot in 2023.

;

;At Chapin High School in the state of South Carolina, some students said that a teacher made them feel “;ashamed; to be Caucasian.” The teacher, they said, assigned them to read Ta-Nehisi Coates' ;Between the World and Me;. The book is an open letter to his son about police violence against Black people. It won the National Book Award in 2015. The school removed the book from the study program.

;

;In Front Royal, Virginia, local officials are planning to cut money for the Samuels Public Library. The move follows complaints from conservatives about books about gay, lesbian and transgender issues.

;

;Iowa Governor Kim Reynolds recently signed into law a bill that calls for books describing sex acts to be removed from school libraries.

;

;The ALA's opposition to book bans has also led some communities to withdraw their membership or support, including Campbell County in Wyoming and a local library in Midland, Texas. Missouri officials announced the state would withdraw support from the ALA after new laws limiting young people's ability to get books considered unacceptable for children.

;

;“I think this ;trend; is going to continue,” Caldwell-Stone said, “at least for as long these groups want to go after whole ;categories; of books.”

;

;I'm Faith Pirlo.

; Thu, 21 Sep 2023 06:07:03 +0800 Former Argentine Torture Center Added to UNESCO Heritagehttps://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/former-argentine-torture-center-added-to-unesco-heritage/7276382.html
;;Wed, 20 Sep 2023 21:58:00 GMT;
;;
;;Photographs of people who disappeared during Argentina's dictatorship are displayed on the wall where students walk through the ESMA Museum and Site of Memory on Sept. 19, 2023. (AP Photo/Rodrigo Abd);
;

;Argentina has welcomed a United Nations decision to include a former secret detention and torture center as a World Heritage site.

;

;A UN Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) conference in Saudi Arabia agreed this week to include the ESMA Museum and Site of Memory on its list of places “considered to be of outstanding value to humanity.”

;

;The former Navy School of Mechanics, known as ESMA, is in the Argentinian capital, Buenos Aires. It contained the most infamous illegal detention center that operated during Argentina's last dictatorship --- from 1976 through 1983. It now operates as a museum and a larger site of memory, including offices for government agencies and human rights organizations.

;

;Argentina's President Alberto Fernández praised UNESCO's decision in a video message. The memory must be kept alive, he said, “so that no one in Argentina forgets or denies the horrors that were experienced there.”

;

;Fernández later said to the United Nations General Assembly in New York on Tuesday afternoon: “By actively ;preserving; the memory that denialists want to ;conceal;, we will prevent that pain from ;recurring;.”

;
;;;A man walks around one of the halls used as a detention and torture center, in the Argentine Navy School of Mechanics, ESMA, Museum and Site of Memory in Buenos Aires, Argentina, Tuesday, Sept. 19, 2023. (AP Photo/Rodrigo Abd);
;

;It is estimated that some 5,000 people were detained at the ESMA during the dictatorship. Many detainees were tortured and later disappeared. It also housed many who were later thrown into the ocean or rivers from planes known as “death flights.”

;

;The ESMA also housed pregnant women brought from other illegal detention centers. They were kept there until they gave birth and their babies were later taken away by military officers.

;

;Argentina's Human Rights Secretary Horacio Pietragalla Corti praised the decision to recognize the site. He said it is a strong answer “to those who deny or seek to downplay state terrorism and the crimes of the last civil-military dictatorship.”

;

;A video posted on social media by Argentina's Foreign Ministry showed the official with tears in his eyes as he celebrated the UNESCO decision.

;

;Pietragalla was one of the babies taken by military officers and raised under a false identity. The group Grandmothers of Plaza de Mayo discovered his birth history, as well as those of 132 other stolen babies through genetic testing.

;

;Argentina has done more than any other Latin American country to bring crimes of former dictatorships to trial. It has held almost 300 trials, all linked to crimes against humanity, since 2006.

;

;The ESMA's addition to the World Heritage list speaks to more than just Argentina. Pietragalla called the recognition “a ;tribute; to the thousands of disappeared individuals in our continent.”

;

;I'm Caty Weaver.

;

;

;

;;The Associated Press reported this story. Hai Do adapted the story for Learning English.;

; Thu, 21 Sep 2023 06:07:03 +0800 Google Links Bard AI Tool to Its Other Productshttps://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/google-links-bard-ai-tool-to-its-other-products/7276373.html
;;Wed, 20 Sep 2023 22:05:35 GMT;
;;
;;In this file photo, various Google logos are displayed on a Google search, Monday, Sept. 11, 2023, in New York. (AP Photo/Richard Drew, File);
;

;Google has linked its Bard artificial intelligence (AI) tool to its Gmail service and other company offerings. The American-based search engine company says the change will permit its users to easily use the AI technology across different product areas.

;

;;Bard; is a chatbot, a computer-driven system designed to interact smoothly with humans and perform high-level writing. Such tools are also known as “generative AI” or “large language models.”

;

;The first widely released chatbot was ChatGPT. It was launched by technology company OpenAI late last year. Google announced the launch of its Bard tool last February. And shortly thereafter, Microsoft announced it was redesigning its Bing search engine to include OpenAI's chatbot technology. Microsoft has invested billions of dollars in OpenAI.

;

;In an announcement Tuesday, Google said it had created a system that makes it possible for users to extend the AI tool to other company services, or apps. This brings Bard technology to Google products including Gmail, Drive, YouTube, Maps, etc.

;

;The system to expand the AI tool to other Google apps is called Bard Extensions. Users can decide which apps they want to add Bard to. This can be done by going to Google's Chrome browser and ;following the process; to activate new extensions. For the moment, Bard Extensions is only available in English.

;

;;In a statement; explaining the change, Google gave several descriptions of how users could use Bard with other apps. For example, a user of Gmail could ask Bard to create a ;summary; of all emails dealing with a particular subject.

;

;Another example is a possible solution to someone planning a major family trip. In such a case, a series of Google apps can be used together with Bard.

;

;The user can ask Bard to search through Gmail messages to get available trip dates from the emails of multiple family members. At the same time, a user can ask Bard to use Google Flights to look up flight dates that would work for the trip. Bard can also be used to book available hotel rooms and connect with Google Maps to provide everyone with directions to the airport. And users could also use Bard to find YouTube videos of things to do during the trip.

;

;Another example Google gives is how Bard can link up with other apps to assist someone with a job search. In this case, Google suggests asking Bard to “find my ;resume; titled June 2023 from my Drive and summarize it to a short paragraph personal statement.”

;

;Another new add-on for Bard permits users to invite others into their Bard ;conversations;.

;

;In its announcement, Google also said it had created a way for users to ;verify; whether information produced by the Bard tool is correct or not. This move is seen as an effort by Google to help users get over concerns about its AI system returning false, outdated or damaging results.

;

;Google says the use of Bard's “Google it” ;button; can test the correctness of its results. When people use this button, Bard's results are compared with the results of a Google search on the same subject. Then, Bard points out the differences in its own results compared to information returned from Google search.

;

;Google senior product director Jack Krawczyk told Reuters news agency the company thought it was important to add this ability to help users find the most truthful results.

;

;“We are presenting (Bard) in a way that it admits when it's not confident,” Krawczyk said. He added that the effort is part of a goal by Google to build user trust in generative AI tools, while holding Bard accountable for its performance.

;

;In announcing Bard Extensions, Google promised to protect users' privacy by blocking its employees from seeing any personal information Bard gets from apps such as Gmail or Drive. It said it had also taken steps to prevent data linked to Bard from being used to target users with ads or to train the AI tool.

;

;Krawczyk noted that currently, Bard users can only pull in information from other Google apps. However, he said Google is already working with other companies to be able to connect their apps to Bard in the future.

;

;I'm Bryan Lynn.

;

;

;

; Thu, 21 Sep 2023 06:07:03 +0800 Strange-looking Tomato Can Still Be Tastyhttps://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/strange-looking-tomato-can-still-be-tasty/7266727.html
;;Tue, 19 Sep 2023 21:55:44 GMT;
;;
;;This September 2021 photo provided by Richard Gill shows a tomato with a genetic mutation in North London, England. (Richard Gill @happymrgill via AP);
;

;This is the time of year when many gardeners are harvesting tomatoes. ;Associated Press; gardening expert Jessica Damiano recently reported about the many pictures of strangely shaped tomatoes sent to her from fans of her gardening advice. She said people sometimes question if the tomatoes are okay to eat.

;

;The good news, Damiano said, is that there is nothing wrong with the deformed fruits. Unless otherwise diseased, they are perfectly good for eating. Their unusual appearance does not affect their taste or ;nutritional; value.

;

;;What's going on here?;

;

;If you have ever cut open a tomato, you know they are divided into ;internal; parts, called locules, which contain seeds and a substance called gel. Most tomatoes have about four or five locules; other kinds of the fruit, like cherry tomatoes, contain two or three. Plum or Roma tomatoes have two locules.

;
;;;This June 10, 2018, image provided by Claudia Vos shows a tomato with genetic mutation in Aarschot, Belgium. The anomaly occurs when tomato cells divide abnormally due to hot or cold weather, resulting in an extra segment that develops outside the fruit. (Claudia Vos via AP);
;

;But when a plant experiences temperature extremes, cell division in the developing fruit can go off track. Temperatures over 32 degrees Celsius during the day and 27 overnight can lead the tomato to form an extra locule. But there is not enough room inside a tomato for the extra part, so it grows on the outside of the fruit.

;

;Not every tomato on an affected plant will be deformed, however.

;

;;What are the chances?;

;

;“Under the right conditions (temperatures that are too hot or even too cold), this could affect one or two tomatoes per plant, depending on where they are in the development process and what the (weather) conditions are,” said Timothy McDermott. He is an assistant ;professor; and extension educator at Ohio State University.

;

;The likelihood of one of your tomatoes developing a locule ;oddity; is estimated to be about one in a thousand, McDermott said.

;

;Any tomato can grow an extra locule. But, Damiano noted, ;heirloom; kinds seem more likely to have this genetic ;mutation; than ;hybrids;.; ;

;
;;;This 2022 image provided by Kathy Burrous shows a tomato with genetic mutation in Floral Park, New York. The anomaly occurs when tomato cells divide abnormally due to hot or cold weather, resulting in an extra segment that develops outside the fruit. (Kathy Burrous via AP);
;

;;Hot tomato?;

;

;The extra-locule mutation is not the only abnormality caused by extreme heat. Conditions including sunscald, ;blossom; drop, halted fruit formation and ;ripening; can also arise when plants are grown outside their usual temperature limit.

;

;Provide ;shade; for your plants when temperatures are predicted to remain above 32 degrees Celsius for several days. Attach a piece of 40 to 50 percent shade cloth to stakes inserted into the ground around the plant. Leave it in place from 12 to 4 pm, when the sun is at its strongest. Then remove it to avoid problems caused by a lack of sunlight.

;

;And, when harvesting your crop, remember: the funny-looking tomatoes taste just as good!

;

;I'm Caty Weaver.

;

;

;

;;Jessica Damiano reported this story for the Associated Press. Caty Weaver adapted it for VOA Learning English.;

; Wed, 20 Sep 2023 06:07:03 +0800 US Senate Permits More Clothing Choiceshttps://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/us-senate-permits-more-clothing-choices/7274865.html

;

;The US Senate's majority leader said this week that the legislative body will no longer enforce a dress code on its floor. A dress code is a set of rules about what may and may not be worn.

;

;Senator Chuck Schumer, the majority leader, said in a statement, “Senators are able to choose what they wear on the Senate floor. I will continue to wear a ;suit;.”

;

;The change comes after Senator John Fetterman, a Democrat from Pennsylvania, has been voting from the doorways of the Senate to avoid violating the dress code. While other senators wear business clothes or dresses in the Capitol building, Fetterman usually wears informal clothes like shorts at work.

;

;Schumer did not talk about Fetterman in his statement about the dress code. But the loosening of the dress code will only apply to senators, not other employees.

;

;During his campaign for the US Senate, Fetterman suffered a stroke, a serious medical condition that happens when the brain does not get enough oxygen from the blood. Earlier this year, Fetterman checked himself into a hospital for treatment on depression.

;
;;;FILE - Sen. John Fetterman, D-Pa., gestures as he rides an elevator near the Senate Subway on Capitol Hill on September 6, 2023, in Washington. (AP Photo/Mariam Zuhaib, File);
;

;When Fetterman returned from treatment, he started wearing more informal clothes, which he says make him more ;comfortable.;

;

;The changes in dress code were met with disapproval from some of the Senate's more ;formal; members.

;

;Kansas Sen. Roger Marshall, a Republican, said it is a “sad day in the Senate” and that the people who Fetterman and Schumer represent should be ;embarrassed;.

;

;Republican Sen. Susan Collins of Maine agreed, arguing that the new rules discredit what the Senate represents. “I plan to wear a bikini tomorrow to the Senate floor,” Collins joked. A bikini is what one wears when swimming.

;

;Fetterman said he was not sure if he would start making use of the new rules just yet. He said it is nice to have them as a choice, but he plans to not use them very often and not overuse them.

;

;Fetterman said of his critics, “They're ;freaking; out, I don't understand it.” He said there are more important things they should be working on instead of what he wears.

;

;Not all Republicans were troubled by the change. Missouri Sen. Josh Hawley was wearing ;jeans; on Monday evening. He says he normally wears informal clothes when he flies in from his home state for the first votes of the week.

;

;“Now I can vote from the Senate floor on Mondays,” Hawley said, noting that he usually wears a suit and tie every other day. A tie is a piece of formal clothing.

;

;Nearby, Connecticut Sen. Chris Murphy was also without a tie. The Democrat said he has gotten in trouble with the Senate's official clothes police, called Sergeant-at-Arms, in the past for not wearing a tie on the floor.

;

;“They would tell us when we were doing it wrong,” Murphy said.

;

;It is unclear if the rules for more formal wear were actually written down anywhere. But Schumer's statement means employees will no longer criticize senators for their choice of clothing or ask them to vote from the doorway.

;

;“I think we should all want to be more comfortable,” Fetterman told a group of reporters on Monday. He added that now that they have that choice, and if people want to wear a suit, “… then that's great.”

;

;I'm Gregory Stachel.
